awd_titl_txt: I-Corps:  A Novel Approach to Sanitize Fresh Produce, Food-Contact Surfaces, and Wash Water Using Micro/nanobubbles
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project will be improvement of the microbial safety of fresh produce in a cost-effective, efficient, and non-toxic way.  Sanitizing systems were valued at an estimated $250 M in 2019. Washing with chlorine remains the predominant industrial choice for minimizing pathogen contamination, but it is imperfect.  Moreover, chlorine can readily react with dissolved organic matter released from fresh produce, causing the depletion of free chlorine and the generation of harmful chemical by-products. The reduction/elimination of chemicals will help maintain the nutritional value, prolong shelf life, and increase the market size of fresh produce. The proposed innovation can be implemented into current produce processing systems for sanitizing the produce, food-contact surfaces, and wash water to partially/fully to replace chemical sanitizers.  In addition to the produce market, this innovation could be applied to adjacent food processing industries and beyond, such as medical and cosmetic industries.

This I-Corps project involves micro/nanobubbles (MNBs) for sanitizing fresh produce, produce-contact surfaces, and the wash water for fresh produce industries. Chlorine systems can only achieve 1-2 log cycle reduction of common pathogens. The proposed system offers greater removal efficiencies of bacteria and colloids from various surfaces using MNBs and MNBs in a combination of surfactants. MNBs are gaseous entities (at micro- and nano- size range) characterized by: relatively stable lifetimes (up to months), negatively charged surfaces, extremely high contact angles and interfacial areas/energies, neutral buoyancy, reduced friction, and ability to generate reactive oxygen species (ROS). These characteristics are highly desirable for cleaning purposes. MNBs have been shown to be effective in many applications, such as cleaning of medical equipment and wastewater treatment. We aim to identify the key MNB properties (e.g., size distribution, concentration, stability, zeta-potential), the most effective solution combinations, and procedures on pathogen removal and inactivation efficacy.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
We are developing a novel and cost-effective method to sanitize fresh produce, food contact surfaces and wash water using miro/nanobubble (MNBs), which is based on physicochemical interactions between bacteria and air-filled MNBs. Using MNBs to disinfect surfaces and wash water has previously shown promising efficiencies in applications such as flotation and wastewater treatment. However, its potential market values and impacts in fresh produce cleaning are not well studied and validated.

In this project, our team, which included an Entrepreneurial Lead, Technical Lead, Industrial Mentor and Principal Investigator performed extensive customer discovery on fresh produce cleaning. Specially, we interviewed 323 experts and practitioners throughout the entire fresh produce supply chain, including experts from fresh produce associations and federal agencies, growers, processors, distributors, retailers, service providers, and individual consumers. We learned that fresh produce industries in the US mainly rely on washing produce with chlorine-based sanitizers for minimizing the microbial contamination, However, over 60% of them have the following concerns with the use of chlorine: 1) it has limited disinfecting efficiency and can only achieve a 1-2 log cycle reduction of common pathogens in fresh produce; 2) it is difficult and time-consuming to control chlorine level as chlorine reacts with the DOM released from fresh produce that decreases its efficiency; technicians are needed to monitor the chlorine level frequently; and 3) chlorine washing leaves harmful chemical residues on the produce. Accordingly, alternatives that can replace or reduce the use of chemical sanitizers while ensuring fresh produce safety and quality are urgently needed. Our MNB-based technology can potentially alleviate those concerns; therefore, we believe that the implementation of it in fresh produce industry has high market potential.

The project helped us determine our target markets, which are fresh produce processing plants and large-scale soil-based farm. We also validated the main value propositions of our innovation, including 1) increase pathogen reduction by at least 1.5 log (compared to baseline chlorine); 2) reduce the use of sanitizers by 50% to minimize health concerns for washing operators and produce consumers; 3) reduce cross-recontamination of fresh produce by simultaneously sanitizing wash water; 4) help maintain fresh produce quality and extend its shelf life.

Overall, this project provided us opportunities to perform customer discovery and market validation. It helped us discover the existing and emerging problems and constraints within the fresh produce industry, which are essential factors to improve our technology to serve our target market's needs. Based on the insight gained from this project, our team will continue our efforts on scientific discovery, method development, expanding networks and partnerships, and market validation to get, keep, and grow customer relationship.
